title: ABC shops decision will cost jobs
text:
View Photo 

Walking into an ABC Shop to pick up DVDs of a favourite show or a stuffed Banana in Pyjama will soon be a thing of the past. 
The national broadcaster is phasing out its 50 stores around Australia and moving its retail operation online, affecting up to 300 employees. 
"There will be significant job losses," ABC managing director Mark Scott told ABC radio on Thursday. 
"It's a sad day for them." 
The ABC says it's no longer possible "to sustain a large network of leased stores", traditionally reliant on sales of DVDs and CDs. 
But ABC DVDs, music, books, toys and merchandise will still be available through ABC Shop Online and other retailers. 
"The ABC is confident that this new strategy will ensure continued audience engagement," head of ABC Retail, Regina Hoekstra, said in a statement. 
"Consumers will still be able to purchase much-loved content both online and in stores." 
The ABC retail division has 50 standalone stores and 78 ABC Centres located in other outlets, as well as ABC Shop Online, employing up to 300 people. 
Each year, about 1000 new consumer products are created, licensed or released by ABC Commercial.
